title: Modifying plots
code: p +   labs(title = 'My comments on the results',        subtitle = NULL,        caption = 'December 2021',        x = 'Mean diff b/t treatment and control')

title: Modifying plots
code: p +    theme_classic() # set the theme for all plots within this R session theme_set(theme_bw())

code: @Manual{,   title = {plotBart: Diagnostic and Plotting Functions to Supplement bartCause},   author = {Joseph Marlo and George Perrett},   year = {2022},   note = {https://priism-center.github.io/plotBart/, https://github.com/priism-center/plotBart}, }

what: Diagnostic and Plotting Functions to Supplement bartCause
title: Diagnostic and Plotting Functions to Supplement bartCause
text: plotBart diagnostic plotting package bartCause thinkCausal.
code: library(plotBart) data(lalonde) confounders <- c('age', 'educ', 'black', 'hisp', 'married', 'nodegr')  # fit BART model model_results <- bartCause::bartc(   response = lalonde[['re78']],   treatment = lalonde[['treat']],   confounders = as.matrix(lalonde[, confounders]),   estimand = 'ate',   commonSup.rule = 'none',   verbose = FALSE,   keepTrees = TRUE )  # plot common support plot_common_support(.model = model_results) # plot CATE and manipulate ggplot object plot_CATE(   .model = model_results,    type = 'density',    ci_80 = TRUE,    ci_95 = TRUE,   .mean = TRUE ) +    labs(subtitle = 'My comments on the results') +   theme_classic()

title: Diagnostic and Plotting Functions to Supplement bartCause

code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github('priism-center/plotBart@*release')

what: Plot the histogram or density of the conditional average treatment effect. — plot_CATE
title: Plot the histogram or density of the conditional average treatment effect. — plot_CATE
text: Plot conditional average treatment effect (CATE) bartCause model. conditional average treatment effect derived form taking fitted BART model making predictions y1 = y|z = 1, X y0 = y|z = 0, X averaging population. plot estimate treatments average effect. Means CATE distribution resemble SATE PATE CATE distribution account uncertainly SATE less uncertainty PATE.

title: Plot the histogram or density of the conditional average treatment effect. — plot_CATE
code: plot_CATE(   .model,   type = c("histogram", "density"),   ci_80 = FALSE,   ci_95 = FALSE,   reference = NULL,   .mean = FALSE,   .median = FALSE )

title: Plot the histogram or density of the conditional average treatment effect. — plot_CATE
text: .model model produced bartCause::bartc() type histogram density ci_80 TRUE/FALSE. Show 80% credible interval? ci_95 TRUE/FALSE. Show 95% credible interval? reference numeric. Show vertical reference line value .mean TRUE/FALSE. Show mean reference line .median TRUE/FALSE. Show median reference line

title: Plot the histogram or density of the conditional average treatment effect. — plot_CATE
text: ggplot object

title: Plot the histogram or density of the conditional average treatment effect. — plot_CATE
text: George Perrett, Joe Marlo

title: Plot the histogram or density of the conditional average treatment effect. — plot_CATE
code: data(lalonde) confounders <- c('age', 'educ', 'black', 'hisp', 'married', 'nodegr') model_results <- bartCause::bartc(  response = lalonde[['re78']],  treatment = lalonde[['treat']],  confounders = as.matrix(lalonde[, confounders]),  estimand = 'ate',  commonSup.rule = 'none' ) #> fitting treatment model via method 'bart' #> fitting response model via method 'bart' plot_CATE(model_results) #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

title: Plot icates — plot_ICATE
text: Plots histogram individual conditional average treatment effects (ICATE). ICATEs difference individuals predicted outcome treatment predicted outcome control averaged individual. Plots ICATEs useful identify potential heterogeneous treatment effects different individuals. ICATE plots can grouped discrete variables.

title: Plot icates — plot_ICATE
code: plot_ICATE(.model, .group_by = NULL, n_bins = 30, .alpha = 0.7)

title: Plot icates — plot_ICATE
text: .model model produced bartCause::bartc() .alpha transparency histograms group.grouping variable vector nbins number bins

title: Plot icates — plot_ICATE
text: ggplot object

title: Plot icates — plot_ICATE
text: George Perrett

title: Plot icates — plot_ICATE
code: data(lalonde) confounders <- c('age', 'educ', 'black', 'hisp', 'married', 'nodegr') model_results <- bartCause::bartc(  response = lalonde[['re78']],  treatment = lalonde[['treat']],  confounders = as.matrix(lalonde[, confounders]),  estimand = 'ate',  commonSup.rule = 'none' ) #> fitting treatment model via method 'bart' #> fitting response model via method 'bart' plot_ICATE(model_results, lalonde$married)

text: Joe Marlo

what: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule or both — plot_common_support
title: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule or both — plot_common_support
text: Plot common support based standard deviation rule, chi squared rule .  Returns ggplot common support plot.

title: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule or both — plot_common_support
code: plot_common_support(.model, rule = c("both", "sd", "chi"))

title: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule or both — plot_common_support
text: .model model produced bartCause::bartc() rule one c('', 'sd', 'chi') denoting rule use identify lack support

title: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule or both — plot_common_support
text: ggplot object

title: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule or both — plot_common_support
text: Sufficient overlap/common support assumption causal inference. BART models use uncertainly counter factual uncertainty. posterior distribution individuals counter factual prediction extends beyond specified cut-point point likely insufficient common support. bartCause model offer option automatically remove points without common support analyses, however, must specified model fitting. Cut-points determined one two rules standard deviation (sd) chi-squared (chi). standard deviation rule, point weak common support posterior distribution counter factual deviation grater maximum posterior observed predictions 1 standard deviation distribution standard deviations individuals predicted outcome observed assignment. chi-squared rule point discarded variance counter factual prediction observed prediction statistically different chi-squared distribution 1 degree freedom. details discard rules see Hill Su 2013. called plot show many points removed standard deviation chi-squared rules. plot used diagnostic bartCause models fit without common-support rule.

title: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule or both — plot_common_support
text: Hill, J., & Su, Y. S. (2013).  Assessing lack common support causal inference using Bayesian nonparametrics: Implications evaluating effect breastfeeding children's cognitive outcomes.  Annals Applied Statistics,  1386-1420.

title: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule or both — plot_common_support
text: George Perrett, Joe Marlo

title: Plot common support based on the standard deviation rule, chi squared rule or both — plot_common_support
code: # \dontrun{ data(lalonde) confounders <- c('age', 'educ', 'black', 'hisp', 'married', 'nodegr') model_results <- bartCause::bartc(  response = lalonde[['re78']],  treatment = lalonde[['treat']],  confounders = as.matrix(lalonde[, confounders]),  estimand = 'ate',  commonSuprule = 'none' ) #> fitting treatment model via method 'bart' #> fitting response model via method 'bart' plot_common_support(model_results)  # }

title: Loess plot of a continuous moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_loess
text: Plot Loess prediction ICATEs continuous covariate. alternative partial dependency plots assess treatment effect heterogeneity continuous covariate. See Carnegie, Dorie Hill 2019.

title: Loess plot of a continuous moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_loess
code: plot_moderator_c_loess(.model, moderator, line_color = "blue")

title: Loess plot of a continuous moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_loess
text: .model model produced bartCause::bartc() moderator moderator vector line_color color loess line

title: Loess plot of a continuous moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_loess
text: ggplot object

title: Loess plot of a continuous moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_loess
text: Carnegie, N., Dorie, V., & Hill, J. L. (2019).  Examining treatment effect heterogeneity using BART.  Observational Studies, 5(2), 52-70.

title: Loess plot of a continuous moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_loess
text: George Perrett, Joe Marlo

title: Loess plot of a continuous moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_loess
code: # \dontrun{ data(lalonde) confounders <- c('age', 'educ', 'black', 'hisp', 'married', 'nodegr') model_results <- bartCause::bartc(  response = lalonde[['re78']],  treatment = lalonde[['treat']],  confounders = as.matrix(lalonde[, confounders]),  estimand = 'ate',  commonSuprule = 'none' ) #> fitting treatment model via method 'bart' #> fitting response model via method 'bart' plot_moderator_c_loess(model_results, lalonde$age)  # }

title: Partial dependency plot of a continuous moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_pd
text: .model model produced bartCause::bartc() moderator moderator vector n_bins number bins cut moderator . Defaults lesser 15 number distinct levels moderator

title: Partial dependency plot of a continuous moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_pd
text: ggplot object

title: Partial dependency plot of a continuous moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_pd
text: Partial dependency plots one way evaluate heterogeneous treatment effects vary values continuous covaraite. information partial dependency plots BART causal inference models see Green Kern 2012.

title: Partial dependency plot of a continuous moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_pd
text: Green, D. P., & Kern, H. L. (2012).  Modeling heterogeneous treatment effects survey experiments Bayesian additive regression trees.  Public opinion quarterly, 76(3), 491-511.

title: Partial dependency plot of a continuous moderating variable — plot_moderator_c_pd
text: George Perrett, Joe Marlo

what: Plot a single regression tree of covariates on ICATEs — plot_moderator_search
title: Plot a single regression tree of covariates on ICATEs — plot_moderator_search
text: Plot single regression tree exploratory heterogeneous effects. Fit single regression tree bartc() icates produce variable importance plot. plot useful identifying potential moderating variables. Tree depth may set depths 1, 2 3. Terminal nodes signal Conditional Average Treatment effect within levels moderation variables. Trees differerent values across terminal nodes suggest strong treatment effect moderation.

title: Plot a single regression tree of covariates on ICATEs — plot_moderator_search
code: plot_moderator_search(.model, max_depth = c(2, 1, 3))

title: Plot a single regression tree of covariates on ICATEs — plot_moderator_search
text: .model model produced bartCause::bartc(). Typically store$model_results max_depth one c(1, 2, 3). Maximum number node levels within tree. 2 recommended

title: Plot a single regression tree of covariates on ICATEs — plot_moderator_search
text: ggplot object

title: Plot a single regression tree of covariates on ICATEs — plot_moderator_search
text: George Perrett, Joe Marlo

title: Plot a waterfall — plot_waterfall
text: Plots point posterior intervals individuals ICATE ordered ICATE continuous variable. Points can colored discrete variable. Waterfall plots useful visual diagnostic possible treatment effect heterogeneity. flat line implies little treatment effect heterogeneity steeper curve implies treatment effect varies across individuals sample. Ordering points continuous variable coloring points discrete variable can helpful identity potential moderators treatment effect.

title: Plot a waterfall — plot_waterfall
code: plot_waterfall(   .model,   descending = TRUE,   .order = NULL,   .color = NULL,   .alpha = 0.5 )

title: Plot a waterfall — plot_waterfall
text: .model model produced bartCause::bartc() descending order icates value? .order vector representing customer order .color vector representing colors .alpha transparency value [0, 1]

title: Plot a waterfall — plot_waterfall
text: ggplot object

title: Plot a waterfall — plot_waterfall
text: George Perrett

title: Plot a waterfall — plot_waterfall
code: # \dontrun{ data(lalonde) confounders <- c('age', 'educ', 'black', 'hisp', 'married', 'nodegr') model_results <- bartCause::bartc(  response = lalonde[['re78']],  treatment = lalonde[['treat']],  confounders = as.matrix(lalonde[, confounders]),  estimand = 'ate',  commonSuprule = 'none' ) #> fitting treatment model via method 'bart' #> fitting response model via method 'bart' plot_waterfall(model_results)  # }

plotBart 0.1.4
text: propensity_scores() longer exported Removed legend argument plot_moderator_c_pd(). Legend can modified using p + theme(legend.position = "<position>") plot_overlap_pScores() propensity_scores() now pass additional arguments bartCause::bartc() enables seed setting

title: plotBart 0.1.3
text: Homogenized function argument names across functions. code breaking previous argument names supported. plot_moderator_search() now returns ggplot object instead rpart.plot object

title: plotBart 0.1.2
text: Fixed bug waterfall plot

title: plotBart 0.1.0
text: Initial release
